snippet: Is he really a weaker not-Romney alternative than Rick Perry or Newt Gingrich?
abstract: Is he really a weaker not-Romney alternative than Rick Perry or Newt Gingrich?
lead_paragraph: The conventional wisdom holds that Rick Santorum's last-minute bid to consolidate the not-Mitt Romney vote in Iowa is, like so many other developments in this election season, nothing but good news for Romney - because Santorum's rise is preventing Rick Perry or Newt Gingrich from gaining ground instead, and in a drawn-out campaign Romney would ultimately "be more threatened by Gingrich or Perry" (as HotAir's Ed Morrissey puts it) than by the former Pennsylvania senator. "On record, on economic conservative credibility, on ties to big donors," Dave Weigel writes, "Santorum's not the opponent Romney feared most." "If Perry or Gingrich are in the top three, we have a real race headed into South Carolina," Erick Erickson suggests. But if Santorum wins Iowa, "we might as well sit back and declare Mitt Romney the nominee." (Judging by these quotes, the Romney camp seems to agree.)
